title: The Fall of Pharaoh
shortSummary: Ezekiel 31 presents a vivid allegory comparing Assyria and Pharaoh to a majestic cedar tree that was exalted but ultimately brought low by God's judgment. The chapter warns against pride and self-exaltation, illustrating how even the greatest powers are subject to God's sovereign authority and will face downfall for their wickedness.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, prophetic ministry of Ezekiel

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The king of Egypt addressed in this chapter, symbolized as a great cedar tree whose pride leads to his downfall.

keyCharacters.name: The Assyrian
keyCharacters.description: Represented as a majestic cedar tree in Lebanon, symbolizing a powerful empire exalted by God’s blessings but ultimately judged for pride.

keyCharacters.name: Son of Man (Ezekiel)
keyCharacters.description: The prophet to whom God speaks, charged with delivering this message of warning and judgment to Pharaoh and his multitude.

definitions.definition: A large, majestic tree native to Lebanon, often used in Scripture to symbolize strength, beauty, and exaltation.
A biblical phrase referring to the realm of the dead or Sheol, the place of the departed.
Nations or peoples who do not worship the true God, often used in the Old Testament to describe Gentile nations.
Another term for the grave or the realm of the dead, symbolizing destruction and final judgment.

outline.heading: Introduction and Divine Command
outline.description: God instructs Ezekiel to speak to Pharaoh and his multitude, challenging Pharaoh to consider to whom he compares himself in greatness.

outline.heading: The Assyrian as a Majestic Cedar
outline.description: The Assyrian empire is depicted as a towering cedar tree in Lebanon, exalted by abundant waters and envied by all trees in Eden, symbolizing its former glory and influence.

outline.heading: Judgment Pronounced on the Proud Cedar
outline.description: Because of pride and self-exaltation, God declares that the mighty cedar will be cut down by foreign nations, and all trees that drink water are warned not to exalt themselves.

outline.heading: The Mourning and Consequences of the Fall
outline.description: God describes the mourning caused by the cedar’s fall, the shaking of nations, and the descent of the mighty into the grave, emphasizing the certainty of judgment.

outline.heading: Final Warning to Pharaoh
outline.description: Pharaoh is directly compared to the fallen cedar and warned that he too will be brought down to the nether parts of the earth among the slain and uncircumcised.

application: Guard against pride and self-exaltation, recognizing that all authority and greatness come from God and are subject to His judgment.
Trust in God's sovereignty over nations and rulers, knowing that He raises up and brings down according to His righteous will.
Find comfort in God's justice, understanding that wickedness and arrogance will not go unpunished, encouraging repentance and humility.
Encourage prayer for leaders to seek God's wisdom and humility rather than relying on their own strength or power.

keyVerses.text: Behold, the Assyrian was a cedar in Lebanon with fair branches, and with a shadowing shroud, and of an high stature; and his top was among the thick boughs.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the metaphor of Assyria’s former greatness and exaltation, illustrating how God’s blessings manifest in power and influence.

keyVerses.text: I have therefore delivered him into the hand of the mighty one of the heathen; he shall surely deal with him: I have driven him out for his wickedness.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God’s active judgment against pride and wickedness, demonstrating His control over the fate of nations.

keyVerses.text: To the end that none of all the trees by the waters exalt themselves for their height, neither shoot up their top among the thick boughs, neither their trees stand up in their height, all that drink water: for they are all delivered unto death, to the nether parts of the earth, in the midst of the children of men, with them that go down to the pit.
keyVerses.significance: This verse serves as a solemn warning against pride and self-exaltation, emphasizing the inevitability of death and judgment.

keyVerses.text: To whom art thou thus like in glory and in greatness among the trees of Eden? yet shalt thou be brought down with the trees of Eden unto the nether parts of the earth: thou shalt lie in the midst of the uncircumcised with them that be slain by the sword. This is Pharaoh and all his multitude, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: The closing verse directly applies the allegory to Pharaoh, underscoring the certainty of his downfall and judgment.
